question:
A teacher makes the following statement to her class: 'If you get an A on the final exam, then you will pass the course.' Which of the following situations would prove that the teacher's statement is false?

A) A student gets an A on the final exam and passes the course.
B) A student gets an A on the final exam and fails the course.
C) A student does not get an A on the final exam and passes the course.
D) A student does not get an A on the final exam and fails the course.
answer:
The correct answer is B.

To analyze this problem, we need to understand the logical structure of conditional statements. The teacher's statement has the form 'If P, then Q', where:
P = 'you get an A on the final exam'
Q = 'you will pass the course'

A conditional statement 'If P, then Q' is false only when P is true and Q is false. In other words, the only way to prove the teacher's statement false is to find a case where a student gets an A on the final exam (P is true) but fails the course (Q is false).

Let's examine each option:

A) A student gets an A (P is true) and passes the course (Q is true). This satisfies the conditional statement, so it doesn't prove the statement false.

B) A student gets an A (P is true) and fails the course (Q is false). This contradicts the conditional statement, so it proves the statement false.

C) A student does not get an A (P is false) and passes the course (Q is true). When the antecedent (P) is false, the conditional statement is automatically true regardless of the consequent (Q). This doesn't prove the statement false.

D) A student does not get an A (P is false) and fails the course (Q is false). When the antecedent (P) is false, the conditional statement is automatically true regardless of the consequent (Q). This doesn't prove the statement false.

Therefore, B is the only situation that would prove the teacher's statement false.
